channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Race for Latest Class of Nuclear Arms Threatens to Revive Cold War
item.media:description: A Russian intercontinental ballistic missile that can carry four miniaturized nuclear warheads was paraded through Red Square in Moscow last May.
item.description: Buildups by the United States, Russia and China unsettle the balance of destructive force that has kept the nuclear peace for more than a half-century.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Russian Enclave Seen as a Fault Line of East-West Tensions
item.media:description: Fishermen casting from a breakwater in February as a ship from the Baltic Fleet sailed from the port of Baltiysk in Russia’s westernmost province.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Kaliningrad, a part of Russia on the Baltic Sea, has become heavily armed amid tensions with the West.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Earthquake in Ecuador Kills More Than 230, President Says
item.media:description: Residents outside a house destroyed by an earthquake in Pedernales, Ecuador, on Sunday.
item.description: At least 233 people were killed and hundreds more injured, President Rafael Correa said, in an earthquake that struck the Ecuador coast on Saturday evening.
item.dc:creator: MAGGY AYALA and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Brazil Transfixed as Votes Are Cast on Impeaching Dilma Rousseff
item.media:description: Eduardo Cunha, seated at left, the president of the lower house of Brazil’s Congress, during a session in Brasília on Sunday to discuss the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff.
item.description: A vote in the lower house of Congress on whether to advance impeachment proceedings could determine the fate of President Dilma Rousseff.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Israel Will Never Give Golan Heights to Syria, Netanyahu Vows
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, center, with Israeli ministers before a cabinet meeting in the Golan Heights on Sunday.
item.description: During a cabinet meeting held in the Israeli-controlled portion of the territory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called on the world to recognize Israel’s sovereignty there.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: U.S. Plans to Step Up Military Campaign Against ISIS
item.media:description: People fled their homes during fighting between Iraqi security forces and the Islamic State in Hit, a city in the Anbar Province, on Wednesday.
item.description: The administration is considering expanding its involvement in Iraq and Syria, and may announce its new plans in the next several days.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pope Francis Takes 12 Refugees Back to Vatican After Trip to Greece
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving Saturday at the Moria detention center on the Greek island of Lesbos, where refugees are held as they await rulings on their asylum applications.
item.description: The pontiff visited Lesbos, the heart of Europe’s migrant crisis, asking for deeper sympathy at a moment when attitudes are hardening.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Head of British Spying Agency Apologizes for Its Treatment of Gays
item.media:description: Robert Hannigan, left, the director of the Government Communications Headquarters. He told a gathering organized by the human rights group Stonewall that the agency needed “people who dare to think differently.”
item.description: The director of the Government Communications Headquarters said a ban on gays like Alan Turing had caused long-lasting psychological damage to many and also hurt the agency.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A New Sense of Fragility in Japanese Town Struck Twice by Quakes
item.media:description: Damaged houses in Mashiki, Japan, on Sunday. The mostly wooden homes in the town crumbled in two earthquakes which struck late Thursday evening and early Saturday morning.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: People in Mashiki had known a network of fault lines ran under their town. But no major quake had struck in anyone’s lifetime, until two did last week.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Do Earthquakes in Japan and Ecuador Signal an Epidemic? Scientists Say No
item.media:description: A road in Mashiki, Japan, was damaged by the recent earthquakes.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Although two powerful quakes struck on opposite sides of the planet over the weekend, there is no connection between them.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Families of Americans Held by Allies Say U.S. Is Keeping Its Gloves On
item.media:description: The White House was successful in pressuring the Egyptian government to release Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen who carried out a 16-month hunger strike.
item.description: Relatives have complained of a lack of high-level attention from American officials — stemming, they fear, from reluctance to confront Egypt and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Labor Protesters to Resume Guggenheim Demonstrations
item.media:description: Protesters at Guggenheim in May 2015.
item.description: The museum had broken off talks with a group that advocates for workers in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: COLIN MOYNIHAN

item.title: Major Oil Exporters Fail to Agree on Production Freeze
item.media:description: Qatar’s energy minister, Mohammed bin Saleh al-Sada, told a news conference that an agreement was not reached.
item.description: A freeze would have involved little sacrifice on the part of oil producers, but they remained unable to reach an accord.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Ecuador Earthquake Kills at Least 77
item.media:description: People rested in a park in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Sunday after a powerful earthquake.
item.media:credit: Marcos Pin Mendez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The capital city of Quito, more than 100 miles from the quake’s epicenter, felt tremors for nearly 40 seconds, sending residents fleeing into the streets.
item.dc:creator: MAGGY AYALA and CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Raúl Castro Urges Cubans to Remain Alert to U.S. Efforts to Alter Communist System
item.media:description: President Raúl Castro of Cuba speaking at the Cuban Communist Party’s three-day congress on Saturday.
item.description: President Castro told a Communist Party Congress that the United States was using a “different method” to undermine the system.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: German Comic Who Lampooned Erdogan to Extend Break From TV Show
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann, right, with the singer Olli Schulz.
item.media:credit: Henning Kaiser/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The move by Jan Böhmermann seemed intended to tamp down a debate that erupted two weeks ago after he broadcast a lewd poem about the Turkish president.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Bangladeshi Editor, 81, Is Accused in Plot to Kill Leader’s Son
item.media:description: Bangladeshi security officers escort Shafik Rehman, 81, at a court after his arrest on Saturday in Dhaka.
item.description: The arrest of the editor, Shafik Rehman, is the latest in a string of criminal proceedings against journalists in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: More Than 40 in Japan Are Confirmed Dead in Earthquakes
item.media:description: A main street was covered with the debris of a newly collapsed house after a second earthquake hit southwestern Japan, in Mashiki, Kumamoto Prefecture, on Saturday.
item.description: Aftershocks were continuing on the island of Kyushu, and a warning that strong quakes were possible for several more days was issued.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Khilad Journal: Farmers in Arid India Share Camps With Their Cattle
item.media:description: A cattle camp in Latur, India, where farmers are able to get food and water for their cattle.
item.media:credit: Anshuman Poyrekar/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.description: In a nation where cows are both sacred and essential, camps have been set up to preserve them in a drought. But instead of dropping them off, the owners are staying.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Dilma Rousseff’s Former Supporters in Brazil Express Disillusionment
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil.
item.description: As the president faces a possible impeachment, working-class people who brought her party to power say they feel abandoned and want a change.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Iraq in Political Limbo After Stalled Reform Attempts
item.media:description: The Iraqi Parliament speaker Salim al-Jabouri, center, during a news conference in Baghdad on Wednesday. Lawmakers did not reach a quorum for a vote to oust him on Saturday.
item.description: Failed attempts to oust the speaker of parliament and a fresh ultimatum from an influential Shiite cleric have left Iraq in a state of political limbo. Backroom negotiations continued late into the night Saturday between Iraq's powerful political blocs after lawmakers attempting to oust speaker Selim al-Jabouri failed to maintain quorum.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Bernie Sanders Meets With Pope Francis
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders leaving the Vatican on Saturday. He was at the Vatican for a conference on social and economic issues.
item.description: The brief meeting took place on Saturday morning at the Vatican before the pope left for Greece, Mr. Sanders said.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ and YAMICHE ALCINDOR

item.title: Phil Sayer, Voice Behind ‘Please Mind the Gap’ on London Underground, Dies at 62
item.media:description: Phil Sayer in 2014. His was not the only voice cautioning passengers to “mind the gap,” but it is arguably the most familiar one.
item.description: Mr. Sayer, an English voice actor, first recorded messages for the London Underground in 2005. “Mind the gap” has been in use since 1969.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Gunmen Kill Scores of Civilians in Western Ethiopia, Official Says
item.description: The attackers came from South Sudan and killed 140 civilians, including women and children, Ethiopia’s communications minister said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 9 Guantánamo Prisoners From Yemen Are Sent to Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: The United States’ outpost at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, where 80 detainees remain in the wartime prison.
item.description: The transfer of the Yemenis, who have been difficult to resettle, completed a long-sought diplomatic deal ahead of President Obama’s planned visit to the Saudi capital.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Opinion: Syria’s Future: A Black Hole of Instability
item.media:description: Kobani, Syria. Wednesday, October 28, 2015
item.description: Peace talks have restarted, but Bashar al-Assad and the rebels are fighting over a state that is beyond salvaging.
item.dc:creator: THANASSIS CAMBANIS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The End of Catholic Guilt
item.description: Pope Francis is merely acknowledging the obvious. As before, he’s using words to change hearts.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY EGAN

item.title: Feature: The New Europeans
item.media:description: The Mzayek family outside a shelter in Eisenärzt.
item.media:credit: Hellen van Meene for The New York Times
item.description: As refugees stream into Europe, and terror attacks spark security fears, one Bavarian village grapples with newcomers — and with the question of what it means to be German.
item.dc:creator: JAMES ANGELOS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Victims of the Brussels Attacks
item.description: Thirty-five victims from at least eight countries were killed in the attacks. Here are profiles of some of the victims, updated as more names are confirmed.

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
